intro: Aster pauciflorus, commonly known as the few-flowered aster, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the northeastern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters, featuring upright stems covered in fine hairs. Its flowering period occurs in late summer to early autumn, producing small, lavender to purple flowers. The leaves are alternate, lance-shaped, and often have a grayish or fuzzy texture.
